Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Machine Learning Control of Underactuated Mechanical Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The nonlinear underactuated systems represent an important and general
class of problems in robotics which have proven mostly intractable for
analytical and numerical control design paradigms. Machine learning
approaches to underactuated control, which employ approximations to
make numerical optimal control techniques tractable, will have broad
applications from walking robots to the control of aerial vehicles and
fluid systems. Here we pursue a careful analysis of the algorithms
applied to linear time-invariant (LTI) systems. This will contribute
fundamental results on the convergence rate of different learning
algorithms, and the design of robot mechanisms and input-output
"features" which maximize the rate of convergence. Theoretical
results are coupled with experiments on a strongly nonlinear control
problem - a two-link bipedal robot walking over rough terrain.
Acquiring a near optimal feedback policy for this robot would produce
a result that is surprising and compelling (because a simple robot
will be traversing more complicated terrain than has been demonstrated
by any humanoid), but also clear and revealing (because the simplicity
of the robot exposes the fundamental problems in walking and nothing
more). Both theory and experiment allow us to perform a careful
comparison between machine learning control and more mature control
approaches from modern control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the first goals of the program was to develop a series of experimental and simulation tools for studying control design for underactuated mechanical systems.  We have developed numerous physical experiments, ranging from the traditional model underactuated systems (acrobots and cart-poles) to simple walking robots (a small compass gait on a boom with prismatic toes and a large free-walking compass gait with onboard computation, an angle bisecting mechanism, series-elastic actuator prismatic toes -- and even a version with pneumatic toes).  These formed the foundation for the major papers/results and careful experimental evaluation for nearly all of the scientific contributions made under this and other programs in my lab for the last 5 years.  Furthermore, this program supported the initial development of what has become a major open-source software infrastructure for simulation, planning, and control of nontrivial robots and underactuated systems: http://drake.mit.edu


A second goal of the program was to develop specifically machine learning approaches to controlling underactuated systems.  We made a number of contributions along this line, most notably policy gradient methods which could be applied to experimental fluid dynamics and which could exploit the Youla-parameterization that is well known in nonlinear control.  However, it became clear to me that our robots do not yet have the "big data" problem -- we're limited by the number of trials we can run on each experimental robot and the fact that every robot is different.  Instead, we focused our optimization effort on (physics-)model-based approaches instead of data-driven approaches.
The development of model-based optimization approaches to nonlinear control during this program was extremely productive and successful.  Most importantly, this led to our exploration of sums-of-squares optimization as a serious tool for stability verification for nonlinear (closed-loop) robot dynamics, and the extensions of this work towards motion planning and nonlinear feedback design.  This includes our LQR-Trees algorithm and a number of derivatives which have won best paper awards at a number of top conferences.


Finally, this program resulted in the development of what has now become a core graduate robotics class at MIT: Underactuated Robotics.  The enrollment in this class started small, but has now grown to nearly 100 students per term, with roughly equal enrollment from Computer Science, Mechanical Engineering, and Aero/Astro.  This course was put online originally on MIT's OpenCourseWare as a video course (also hosted on youtube), and most recently on edX (http://tiny.cc/mitx-underactuated) and has now served 10's of thousands of students all over the world.
